By Roberta Rampton
| SEATTLE

SEATTLE The financial and political fallout from Britain's vote to leave the European Union has added to a string of setbacks for President Barack Obama as he works to burnish his legacy before his presidency ends in January 2017.The Brexit decision came after a deadlock in the U.S. Supreme Court on Thursday effectively ended Obama's push to overhaul immigration rules
column2: and the week after the worst mass shooting in modern U.S. history.For Obama
column3: the reversals heighten pressure on him and fellow Democrats to work harder for the Nov. 8 elections - particularly for the party's presumptive presidential nominee
column4: Hillary Clinton
column5: who represents his best shot at making sure more of his policies are not rolled back.Speaking at two fundraising events in Seattle on Friday night
column6: at the end of an arduous day that saw global markets plunge after the Brexit vote
column7: Obama acknowledged the shifting political winds four months from the vote.""If you didn't think the stakes were high before
column8: you should think the stakes are pretty high right now
column9: Obama said at an intimate fundraising dinner at the home of tech executive Steve Singh. Guests
column13: 800 per couple.Obama has argued technology and globalization can increase opportunities for all
column14: but conceded that recent events show many people are frightened by global competition and feel left behind.Donald Trump
column15: the presumptive Republican presidential nominee and political novice
column16: has tapped into those concerns about the economy
column17: trade and immigration - fears that also figured into the UK campaign to leave the EU.

column6: according to a Reuters/Ipsos poll released on Friday that showed 46.6 percent of likely American voters supported Clinton while 33.3 percent backed Trump.'THE NINTH INNING'

column1: In April
column2: Obama had taken the unusual step of traveling to London to help the ""Remain"" camp of the referendum for his friend and ally
column3: Prime Minister David Cameron
column4: who will now leave office before Obama does.The financial uncertainty from Brexit threatens to weigh on the strong U.S. economy and undo some of the recovery seen since Obama took office in early 2009 at the height of the financial crisis.Earlier this week
column5: Obama's plan to remove the specter of deportation for millions of undocumented immigrants was quashed when the Supreme Court deadlocked over lifting a hold on the action.

column1: And two weeks ago
column2: the nation's worst mass shooting in modern history
column3: at a gay nightclub in Orlando
column4: raised questions about how Obama is dealing with home-grown extremism - and served as a reminder of his failure to convince the U.S. Congress to tighten gun laws.The setbacks show the limits of action that any president can take unilaterally

It's an argument he said fit in with his own campaign to shake up Washington by renegotiating free trade deals and stopping illegal immigration.""People want to take their country back. They want to have independence in a sense. You see it with Europe

Cameron had called Trump's anti-immigrant policy ideas divisive and wrong.""I think David Cameron is a good man. He was wrong on this.  He didn't get the mood of his country right. He was surprised

Wearing a white hat emblazoned with his ""Make America Great Again"" campaign slogan

column6: which voted 52 percent to 48 percent to leave.Trump

column10: 85 km (53 miles) southwest of Glasgow. (Additional reporting by Doina Chiacu; Editing by Howard Goller)"

WASHINGTON U.S. Democratic presidential hopeful Bernie Sanders said on Friday he would vote for Hillary Clinton to stop Republican Donald Trump from winning the White House
column2: a lukewarm show of support that his campaign said was not a formal endorsement.Sanders' comments come after weeks of pressure from Democratic Party officials to throw his weight behind Clinton

column4: the former U.S. secretary of state

column9: a third-party candidate and staying home
column10: according to Reuters/Ipsos polling. Asked if he would vote for Clinton in November
column13: told MSNBC television: ""Yes. The issue right here is I'm going to do everything I can to defeat Donald Trump. I think Trump in so many ways would be a disaster for this country if he were elected president.""""We do not need a president whose cornerstone of his campaign is bigotry
column14: who is insulting Mexicans and Latinos and Muslims and women
column15: who does not believe in the reality of climate change

column4: deport millions of undocumented immigrants
column5: and build a wall along the U.S.-Mexican border if he is elected. A spokeswoman for Trump's campaign did not immediately respond to a request for comment. The wealthy New York businessman has rejected accusations his proposals are bigoted
column6: and has said his policies would help minorities by bolstering the economy and creating jobs.

column1: Trump has also called climate change a hoax by the Chinese to hurt business in the United States.      Sanders
column2: a self-described democratic socialist
column3: managed to turn his long-shot run into a mass movement with proposals to combat wealth inequality
column4: increase access to healthcare and education
column5: and defend the environment.

column1: His challenge to Clinton
column2: one of the best-known figures in U.S. politics
column3: lasted far longer than expected
column4: running for four months and across 50 states and yielding record numbers of small donations to his campaign.Sanders has said he will continue to push for a liberal agenda heading into the Democratic National Convention in Philadelphia from July 25-28
column5: when Clinton's nomination is expected to become official. He has also made clear he does not want his presence to hurt the party's chances of holding onto the White House. Three-quarters of likely Democratic voters in the general election say Sanders should have a ""major role"" in shaping the party's positions
column6: according to a Reuters/Ipsos poll conducted June 17-21. Nearly two-thirds also said that Sanders should endorse Clinton.  (Additional reporting by Chris Kahn in New York; Richard Valdmanis in Boston; Editing by Jeffrey Benkoe and Jonathan Oatis)"

column1: 5	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-hostages-whitehouse-idUSKCN0ZA3K8	U.S. committed to bringing American hostages home -Obama	"
By Ayesha Rascoe
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON U.S. President Barack Obama on Friday said the United States remains committed to bringing home Americans held captive overseas and helping their families
column2: a year after the administration promised to overhaul its handling of hostage situations.""We will not stop until we can bring our fellow citizens back to their families
column3: Obama said in a statement on the anniversary of the White House's policy review.Obama specifically named journalist Austin Tice who disappeared in Syria in 2012
column4: Caitlan Coleman held in Afghanistan
column5: and retired FBI agent Robert Levinson
column6: who went missing in Iran more than nine years ago.Earlier this week
column7: the families of four Americans killed by Islamic State urged Obama to do everything possible to bring home Tice
column8: the only U.S. journalist known to be held in war-torn Syria.

column1: The parents of the slain hostages criticized Obama for not personally naming Tice in his remarks at this year's White House Correspondents' Association Dinner when Obama said that he would ""fight for the release of American hostages held against their will."" They said Tice's return would be a test of the of the success of the administration's new policy.The White House undertook a six-month review of its hostage policies after complaints from families that their initiatives to free relatives captured abroad had been discouraged and sometimes blocked by government officials.
As part of the overhaul
column2: Obama named James O'Brien special presidential envoy for hostage affairs at the State Department to help coordinate the efforts of law enforcement and diplomats.""But I know our work will not be done until our fellow Americans who are held against their will

column1: By Terry Wade
| HOUSTON
HOUSTON With a number of U.S. states proceeding with investigations of Exxon Mobil Corp's (XOM.N) record on climate change
column2: the attorney general of Massachusetts and investment funds of the Rockefeller family on Friday told a Congressional committee it lacked powers to oversee those probes.The pushback is the latest chapter in a high-stakes fight between the world's largest publicly traded oil company and a coalition of state attorneys general who have said they would go after Exxon to try and force action to tackle climate change.   The House Committee on Science
column3: Space and Technology last week reiterated demands that state attorneys general hand over any records of consultations the prosecutors had with outside environmental groups before their probes were opened.Republicans on the committee have said about 20 state officials overreached when they jointly said in March they would participate in inquiries into whether Exxon executives misled the public by contradicting research from company scientists that spelled out the threats of climate change.

column1: State officials have said the committee has no right to get involved.""The Committee lacks authority to interfere with an investigation by the Massachusetts Attorney General's Office into possible violations of Massachusetts law by ExxonMobil
column2: said a letter to the committee from the office of Massachusetts Attorney General Maura Healey that was seen by Reuters.

column1: In another letter to the House panel seen by Reuters
column2: the Rockefeller Brothers Fund and the Rockefeller Family Fund
column3: two investment funds that have been critical of fossil fuels linked to climate change
column4: said the committee's request ""imperiled the funds' First Amendment rights"" and said ""Congress's investigatory power is not unlimited.""Last week
column5: Exxon asked a federal court to throw out a subpoena that would force it to hand over decades of documents on climate change to Healey's office.

column1: Both sides in the standoff have sought to use the First Amendment of the Constitution
column2: which guarantees freedom speech and freedom of assembly
column3: among other protections
column4: to press their cases. The House committee has complained the inquiries risk stifling free speech and scientific inquiry
column5: and that state officials were coordinating with special interest groups.Exxon
column6: which declined to comment on Friday
column7: has repeatedly said that it has acknowledged the reality of climate change for years and communicated this to investors."

column1: 7	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-lgbt-whitehouse-idUSKCN0ZA35P	New York LGBT bar becomes first U.S. monument to gay rights	"
By Ayesha Rascoe
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON President Barack Obama on Friday designated the site of a watershed event in the history of U.S. gay rights
column2: the 1969 Stonewall riots in New York City
column3: as a national monument
column4: the first to honor the contributions of gay Americans.The Stonewall Inn gay bar in Manhattan's Greenwich Village was the scene of a police raid that triggered riots and ignited a long struggle to bring lesbian
column5: gay
column6: bisexual and transgender people into the American mainstream and guarantee their rights.""Welcome to the family
column7: the National Park Service said in a  tweet welcoming its 412th site.LGBT rights advocacy groups hailed the national recognition
column8: saying it will help highlight the gay communities' continued struggles
column9: especially in the aftermath of the June 12 mass shooting at a gay nightclub in Florida that killed 49 people.""This new national monument will be a source of inspiration to a new generation of Americans across the country standing up for equality and uniting to show the world that love conquers hate
column10: Human Rights Campaign President Chad Griffin said.The move was the latest of several steps Obama has take on  gay rights during his presidency.

column2: he signed a law repealing a policy that had banned gays from serving openly in the U.S. military. In 2012
column3: he became the first president to support gay marriage
column4: a stance he has admitted took time to evolve. His administration also supported the legal challenge that led to the 2015 U.S. Supreme Court ruling legalizing gay marriage nationwide.""There is important distance yet to travel
column5: but through political engagement and litigation
column6: as well as individual acts of courage and acceptance
column7: this movement has made tremendous progress toward securing equal rights and equal dignity
column8: Obama said in a proclamation officially designating the historic site.The events of late June and early July 1969 in New York helped start the modern American gay rights movement.

column1: A week of violent clashes on Christopher Street between patrons of the Stonewall Inn and police
column2: who had periodically raided the bar
column3: arresting gays under morals laws of the era
column4: became known as the Stonewall riots.The crackdown was also tied up in a dispute between the Mafia
column5: which owned the bar
column6: and corrupt police officers seeking payoffs for protection. But it unleashed a year of protests
column7: culminating with the first gay pride parade in 1970.This year's weekend LGBT pride festivities started in New York on Friday with a street fair and were to culminate with Sunday's parade through Lower Manhattan. Events were scheduled across the country in San Francisco

column1: Obama's designation protects about 7.7 acres (3.1 hectares) of land
column2: including the Stonewall Inn and nearby Christopher Park. U.S. lawmakers representing New York
column3: in a statement
column4: called the site ""a beacon for liberation.""It drew renewed attention in the wake of this month's massacre in Orlando at another gay venue
column5: a nightclub called Pulse. Mourners in New York flocked to the inn and created a makeshift memorial after the shooting
column6: the worst such attack in modern U.S. history. In honor of the new monument
column7: the White House will release a video that will be played on billboards in New York's Times Square on Saturday. U.S. officials will also hold a designation ceremony at Stonewall on Monday. (Reporting by Ayesha Rascoe and Susan Heavey; Editing by Will Dunham and Dan Grebler)"

column1: 8	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-brexit-idUSKCN0ZA37F	Could Brexit vote be a preview of U.S. presidential race?	"
By John Whitesides and Luciana Lopez
| WASHINGTON/NEW YORK
WASHINGTON/NEW YORK Britain's stunning vote to leave the European Union
column2: buoyed by a frenzy of nationalism and populist anger
column3: was a crushing rejection of the political elite. Republican Donald Trump hopes it is also a preview of November's U.S. presidential election.The referendum result reverberated immediately in a U.S. presidential campaign dominated by Trump's rapid rise to capture the nomination
column4: fueled by a similar brew of anti-establishment and anti-globalization sentiment.The vote in Britain reinforced the notion that the insurgent campaign launched by the wealthy real estate developer had tapped into a global political movement that might be hard to stop.""This is a protest vote against globalization and there is one presidential candidate who won the nomination who has put globalization in his crosshairs - and that's Donald Trump
column5: Republican strategist John Feehery said.Trump
column6: who has spent much of his campaign warning of the dangers posed by immigrants who illegally enter from Mexico and proposing a temporary ban on U.S. entry for Muslims
column7: has matched the global mood with his rhetoric.""There are swaths of the population around the world who are struggling economically in the current economy
column8: and groping for targets of blame
column10: a political scientist at the University of Wisconsin-Madison.""Trump and the Brexit vote offer up tangible targets
column11: and it is not surprising that people grab onto them. The vote yesterday is a reminder that Trump could very well win the presidential election
column13: Trump was happy to note the parallels to his own campaign when he reopened his golf course in Turnberry
column15: on Friday. Presumptive Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton bemoaned the result.

column1: The referendum
column2: which most British opinion polls had predicted was headed to defeat
column3: was a wake-up call for Democrats who have been heartened by Clinton's lead over Trump in opinion polls of late.""I woke up this morning a little dismayed
column4: said Democratic strategist Dane Strother. ""The question is whether Trump is similarly underperforming in the polls here. If that under-polled anger was present in Britain
column5: as a Democrat you have to hope it isn't mirrored here.""Global stock markets wobbled immediately after the vote
column6: which experts warned could trigger a global recession and weaken the U.S. economy.CAUTIONARY TALE

column1: British Prime Minister David Cameron
column2: who said after the vote he could step down by October
column3: presents a cautionary lesson for Clinton as she prepares to face Trump. British voters ignored repeated warnings from Cameron about the dire consequences of a departure from the European Union.Clinton can take advantage of the unsettled global mood without indulging in predictions of doom or the over-the-top rhetoric that sometimes has set back Trump
column4: Republican strategist Rich Galen said.""She can reflect some of the same sentiment that Trump and the Brexit forces tapped into but use it to her advantage
column5: Galen said. ""She is not going to
column6: and doesn't want to
column8: but the idea is to say
column9: 'I understand these concerns.'""Clinton adviser Jake Sullivan told reporters after the vote that she has ""a real confidence that Americans are generous
column11: big-hearted people"" who believe that the country is stronger together.

column1: They're going to watch what impact (the Brexit vote) ends up having on the U.K. and on the British economy and come November
column2: they are going to make their own decision about the kind of leadership that they're looking for
column3: he said.Differences between the electorates in the United Kingdom and the United States are one reason the Brexit sentiment may not translate fully into success for Trump. About 30 million votes were cast in the last British general election in 2015
column4: with about 10 percent of those cast by minority voters. Polling in the UK ahead of the Brexit vote suggested broad support for staying in the EU among those voters.By contrast
column5: according to the Pew Research Center
column6: nonwhite voters constituted 26 percent of all voters in the 2012 U.S. general election -- and by a huge margin they backed Democratic President Barack Obama. Pew projects that by November
column7: nearly one in three voters will be a minority
column8: and opinion polls show Trump struggling with those blocs.Just being more mature
column9: experienced and sympathetic than Trump may not be enough for Clinton.""The argument is you need a responsible grownup
column10: but a large part of the world doesn't want a responsible grownup
column12: a New Hampshire-based Republican strategist. ""I don't think it's enough to say I know all the stuff he doesn't or he's rash
column13: because right now people aren't filtering that through."" (Additional reporting by Ginger Gibson
column15: Alana Wise and James Oliphant; Editing by Howard Goller and Mary Milliken)"

column1: 9	http://reuters.com/article/us-britain-eu-ttip-idUSKCN0ZA2V0	UK 'Leave' vote deflates hopes for U.S.-EU trade deal	"
By David Lawder
| WASHINGTON

WASHINGTON Britain's looming exit from the European Union is another huge setback for negotiations on a massive U.S.-EU free trade deal that were already stalled by deeply entrenched differences and growing anti-trade sentiment on both sides of the Atlantic. The historic divorce launched by Thursday's vote will almost certainly further delay substantial progress in the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP) talks as the remaining 27 EU states sort out their own new relationship with Britain
column2: trade experts said on Friday. With French and German officials increasingly voicing skepticism about TTIP's chances for success
column3: the United Kingdom's departure from the deal could sink hopes of a deal before President Barack Obama leaves office in January.""This is yet another reason why TTIP will likely be postponed
column4: said Heather Conley
column5: European program director at the Center for Strategic and International Studies
column6: a think tank in Washington.""But to be honest
column10: she said.U.S. Trade Representative Michael Froman said in a statement on Friday that he was evaluating the UK decision's impact on TTIP
column11: but would continue to engage with both European and UK counterparts.    ""The importance of trade and investment is indisputable in our relationships with both the European Union and the United Kingdom
column12: Froman said. ""The economic and strategic rationale for T-TIP remains strong.""

column1: TTIP negotiators are still expected to meet in Brussels in mid-July as scheduled
column2: but those talks were aimed at focusing on less controversial issues while leaving the thorniest disagreements for U.S. and EU political leaders to resolve. And it is unclear when Britain will launch formal separation proceedings
column3: which will take at least two years.But analysts said both sides have been reluctant to put their best offers on the table with a new U.S. president due to take office in January and French and German leadership elections nearing in 2017.The Brexit also will preoccupy EU officials in coming months as they launch their own negotiations with London over the future terms of UK-EU trade
column4: and sort out their post-Brexit priorities
column5: said Hosuk Lee-Makiyama
column6: director of the European Centre for International Political Economy
column7: a Brussels-based think tank.    Britain's departure could leave U.S. negotiators facing a European side that is more dug-in on some issues
column9: a senior fellow at the Peterson Institute for International Economics

column1: As the UK is part of the coalition of liberal trading economies in the EU
column2: the U.S. is losing one of the more like-minded countries from the group in Brussels sitting on the other side of the negotiating table
column3: said Bown
column4: a former World Bank economist.However
column5: Lee-Makiyama
column6: who also sees little chance of a deal before 2018
column7: said Britain's departure could eliminate one source of disagreement because the UK has insisted on a financial services chapter in the trade deal.""The only real proponent of banking regulation in TTIP is the UK. Germany and France are probably willing to let it go
column8: he said. ""It still leaves about 20 outstanding issues at nearly the same level of difficulty.""

column1: The TTIP negotiations
column2: which started three years ago
column3: have unable to settle major differences over agriculture
column4: where the EU side has shown little willingness to alter food safety rules that prohibit American beef raised with hormones or genetically modified foods
column5: or open its closely guarded geographical food naming rules
column6: such as for Asiago and feta cheeses.European negotiators have complained that the United States has offered too little to open up its vast federal
column7: state and local government procurement markets to European vendors with ""Buy American"" preferences in place.Europe also wants access to key U.S. sectors such as maritime transport and aviation
column8: while American negotiators have been frustrated over lack of access to some 200 European sectors ranging from healthcare to education.The two sides also are far apart on how to resolve disputes. The U.S. side favors a traditional binding arbitration approach
column9: while the Europeans want a court-like system that allows for appeals.More progress has been made on harmonizing regulations for things like car seat belt anchors
column10: clothes labeling and pharmaceutical inspections. (Additional reporting by Phil Blenkinsop in Brussels; Editing by Jonathan Oatis)"
